item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Hong Kong Retains Allure as Retail Mecca
item.description: High rents to not detract from Hong Kong’s ability to lure high end retailers, especially with a flood of mainland Chinese spending heavily in the city.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: A busy intersection in Hong Kong's Causeway Bay shopping district in November.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 27
item.description: Austerity pushback in Euyrope; U.S. weighs strategy on Syria; test for immigration overhaul, and Europe small companies face challenge.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times

item.title: North Korea Expected to Charge American
item.description: A tour operator from Washington State is accused of carrying out hostile acts against the North Korean government.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Australian Billionaire Plans New Political Party
item.description: Clive Palmer, who is known for his efforts to build a replica of the Titanic, wants to steers Australian politics in a more conservative direction.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: Dwike Mitchell, Missionary Pianist, Dies at 83
item.description: Mr. Mitchell and his playing partner, Willie Ruff, helped to popularize jazz in places like China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Dwike Mitchell, seated, and Willie Ruff, who together formed a duo known for their thousands of concerts and their travels.

item.title: Frenchman Will Return to China Prized Bronze Artifacts Looted in 19th Century
item.description: The offer to return the objects came from one of 60 high-powered Frenchmen accompanying President François Hollande on his first visit to China.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: A bronze rabbit head is one of two objects to be given back to China. It was looted from the Summer Palace near Beijing during the Second Opium War.

item.title: Central Americans Flow Into Mexico, Bound for U.S.
item.description: Central Americans fleeing crime and economic stagnation are flowing freely across Mexico’s southern border and causing a spike in migration to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants from Central America stow away on a train in Arriaga, in southern Mexico, in an effort to reach the United States.

item.title: Dutch Man Said to Be Arrested in Powerful Internet Attack
item.description: Dutch authorities said the Spanish police arrested a man in connection with an assault on a spam-fighting site that caused widespread Internet congestion.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Tim Tracy Sought to Show Venezuela’s Divide, Friends Say
item.description: Tim Tracy, who was arrested on Wednesday, is accused of plotting to destabilize Venezuela and promoting civil war.
item.dc:creator: By MARÍA EUGENIA DÍAZ and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Tim Tracy, 35, is accused of plotting to destabilize Venezuela and promote civil war.

item.title: Obama Avoids Swift Response to Report on Syria Arms
item.description: The president said he would respond “prudently” and “deliberately” to evidence that Syria has used chemical weapons, tamping down any expectations that he would take swift action.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama met with King Abdullah II of Jordan at the White House on Friday. An administration official said the two discussed coordinating more robust aid for the opposition in Syria.

item.title: E.U. Is Pressed to Reconsider Cuts as Economic Cure
item.description: European officials who favored austerity have adopted a softer tone, backing away from a strategy that is widely unpopular with the public.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Syria Rebels Say Plane from Iraq Bombed Eastern City
item.description: Activists say an attack in the east may have originated in Iraq.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Israel Sees Obama’s Response on Syria as Gauge for Iran
item.description: Israeli leaders say they are watching President Obama’s response to Syria’s apparent use of chemical weapons for clues about how he might handle the Iranian nuclear issue.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: South Korea to Pull Workers From North
item.description: The decision to remove 175 managers from a jointly operated industrial park came hours after North Korea rejected the South’s proposal for talks.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A South Korean military vehicle drives past a checkpoint in Paju that leads to the North Korean border town of Kaesong.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: John Bercow, House of Commons Speaker, Seeks to Quell the Unruly
item.description: As the House of Commons speaker, John Bercow is a zealot on a mission. He wants Britain’s legislators to behave like plausible grown-ups and pipe down.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: "But if you ask me, do I want to be speaker for the kick of putting people down? No. I think that would be a very sad, rather pathetic reason for wanting to be speaker."

item.title: 38 Killed in Fire at Russian Psychiatric Hospital
item.description: Most of the victims were patients who died in their beds as firefighters made the hourlong journey from the nearest station, safety officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Ministry for Emergency Situations workers and fire fighters worked at the site of a fire at a psychiatric hospital Friday morning in the town of Ramensky, near Moscow.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: A President is Arrested
item.description: The police on Friday arrested one of the country’s presidents and 18 other people in a corruption investigation in one of Bosnia-Herzegovina’s two main sections, a prosecution spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bombings in Baghdad
item.description: At least 20 people were killed by bombs in Baghdad on Friday, at the end of a week of bloodshed that prompted a United Nations envoy to warn that Iraq was “at a crossroads.”
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Military to Stop Using Shells Containing Phosphorus
item.description: The Israeli military said on Friday that it planned to remove shells containing phosphorus from active use within about a year.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Rosenberg Family’s Quest to Regain Art Stolen by Nazis
item.description: Three generations of a Parisian art dealer’s family have worked tirelessly to recover Picassos, Cézannes and hundreds of other works.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICIA COHEN and TOM MASHBERG

item.title: Media Decoder: ‘Technical’ Problem Resolved, ‘Django’ to Open in China in May
item.description: The film was pulled from theaters in April, but is now set to debut on May 12. Sony Pictures officials declined to say if the movie had been edited.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY

item.title: Japan Approves Return to Air of Boeing 787
item.description: The authorities approved fixes to the planes’ batteries and authorized All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines, which own about half of the 50 Dreamliners delivered, to resume flights.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and JAD MOUAWAD

item.title: Musharraf Under Arrest on Charges in Bhutto Assassination
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s former military leader, is accused of threatening Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister, before she returned to Pakistan from exile in 2007.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Violent Protests Follow Building Collapse in Bangladesh
item.description: The protests came as rescue teams spent a third day searching for survivors in the rubble of a building that collapsed in a suburb of the capital, killing more than 300.
item.category: Children s Place Retail Stores Inc|PLCE|NASDAQ
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police fired tear gas after relatives of the missing and dead burst into angry protests at the site of a building collapse on Friday in Savar, Bangladesh.

item.title: Shadows of an Old Military Base
item.description: The Subic Bay Freeport in the Philippines was once filled with free-spending American sailors. Now it has both tourist attractions and abandoned American-style homes and buildings.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Subic Bay has become a popular tourist destination for Filipinos seeking to enjoy the beaches and the American legacy of the former military base.
